prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: If only some knowledge is property, then it must be possible to state criteria which will distinguish between knowledge which is property and that which is not. The only criterion which has been suggested is the secrecy of the knowledge. However, some courts have been skeptical of the argument that secrecy in some way creates a proprietary right in knowledge.[1]

One criterion for distinguishing between information which is property and information which carries no property rights may be whether the information has value. Value is acquired through the labour and skill and/or the money expended to discover or create confidential business information which, by reason of the labour, skill or money expended, is not available to all.
F.C.T. v. United Aircraft Corporation (1944), 68 C.L.R. 525 (H.C.), at p. 534, per Latham C.J.
